column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=4. Results and Analysis
#Text=4.1 .
#Text=Population-Sensitive POI Categories

#Text=The PSP categories were selected by spatial association rule mining ( see Section 3.1 ) , which has a strong spatial association with the population hotspots extracted from Easygo heat map data .
#Text=The two parameters of the spatial association rules between the POI categories and the population hotspots are shown in Table 3 .
#Text=Various categories had significant differences in the support and confidence of the association rule between the population hotspots and the POI categories .
#Text=A total of 3092 hotspots were extracted to establish the two-dimensional association rules between population hotspots and POI records .

#Text=The minimum support ( min_sup ) and minimum confidence ( min_conf ) values were determined to analyze the relationship between the number of association rules and different min_sup and min_conf values .
#Text=The number of association rules corresponding to the different min_sup and min_conf values showed obvious regularity (
#Text=Figure 3
#Text=) .
#Text=With increasing min_sup and min_conf values , the number of rules decreased .

#Text=By analyzing the support values and confidence values , it was that some association rules contained certain categories of POIs , such as catering and corporation , that had high support but low confidence .

#Text=This was because many of those POIs had a low proportion of spatial association rules with population aggregation points , which means that those association rules were important but not accurate .
#Text=Other rules , such as the rules containing financial services and scientific research and technical services , had high confident and low support .

#Text=Those categories of POIs were more likely to have association rules with population gathering points , but the number was small , which means that those association rules were accurate but not important .

#Text=To obtain sufficient association rules that were important and improve the accuracy , the values of min_sup and min_conf should be set to be as large as possible and to obtain as many rules as possible at the same time .
#Text=In this study , the value of min_sup was set to 27,450 and the value of min_conf was set to 0.0019 , which is the abscissa of inflection points of
#Text=Figure 3
#Text=a , b.
#Text=Finally , four categories were selected as PSPs , including residential community , wholesale and retail , education services , and resident services .
#Text=The PSPs accounted for only 52 % of the total POI records .
#Text=This means that the other 48 % were PIPs that would have inevitably introduced noise into the dasymetric model if all POIs were used .
#Text=The residential community contained POIs representing residential buildings , apartments , and hotels , where people lived and gathered .

#Text=Wholesale and retail , education service , and resident service were the three categories of POI that were most relevant to people ’s daily life , and they were also the attraction factors for residents .

#Text=Therefore , all the PSP categories selected through the spatial association rule mining were closely related to the spatial distribution of the population and can be used in dasymetric mapping .
#Text=4.2 .
#Text=Population Map from the PSP-Driven Model
#Text=A RF-based dasymetric model was built with all the covariates described in Section 3.2 .
#Text=This model was used to downscale the log-transformed population density in each county .
#Text=The fine-grained population map was built by back-transforming the result of the dasymetric model .
#Text=Figure 4
#Text=shows the value of %IncMSE for each covariate in the RF model .
#Text=The importance of covariates to the PSPs was significantly higher than those of most other the covariates , which shows that PSP had a great impact on the accuracy of the dasymetric mapping .
#Text=In addition to the covariates related to the PSPs , the distance to the nearest build-up area , DEM and NTL also has a large impact on the dasymetric modelling .
#Text=This result is consistent with those of previous studies .
#Text=The fine-gridded population map at a 100-m spatial scale in the experiment showed visually satisfactory results (
#Text=Figure 5
#Text=) .
#Text=Figure 5
#Text=a shows the population distribution map generated by the PSP-driven dasymetric model proposed in Section 3.2 .
#Text=As a comparison , the WorldPop (
#Text=Figure 5
#Text=b ) and the LandScan (
#Text=Figure 5
#Text=c ) datasets from the same region were also shown .
#Text=Generally , the distributions of the population from three datasets were similar and agreed with the actual topography .
#Text=The population of the plains and urban areas in the southeast was significantly higher than those in the mountains and grasslands in the northwest .

#Text=The population was concentrated in the two municipalities of Beijing and Tianjin and aggregated in second-tier cities such as Shijiazhuang and Tangshan , which is consistent with the actual population distribution .
#Text=Nevertheless , the results from the proposed methods also highlight the population gradient around small towns and villages .
